and shadows proceeding from a like alternation of solid substance, and
of hollow spaces beneath (Plate X, Fig <s>11</s>12). This predominance of the
concentric divisions, which gives a very distinctive aspect to the
disks which exhibit it, is usually most apparent in individuals
whose vertical section exhibits two planar cells; and it has
seemed to me to depend on the unusual freedom between the
lat<s>t</s>eral communications, which I have notice in certain
individuals thus formed, so that the animal portion of each
zone might be described as an annulus of sarcode, merely
constricted at intervals. This peculiarly cyclical aspect of the
surface (on whose occurrence in fossil specimens I believe the
genus <u>Cyclolina</u> to have been founded, §5) may pass into either
of the principal types previously noticed; thus in Fig <s>12</s>11 we
observe the concentric zones, though still very strongly marked,
breaking up (so to speak) into bands of rounded cells with slightly
convex covers; whilst in Fig 10, they are subdivided by very
definite transverse lines, into cells of a remarkable squareness, which
still retain the original flatness of their surfaces
